awd_titl_txt: Particle Physics at CMS in the High Luminosity Era
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project aims to better understand the Universe at the smallest scales by probing nature's basic symmetries and their relation to the origin of mass. The 2012 discovery of a Higgs boson with mass close to 125 GeV represents both the crowning achievement of the Standard Model of particle physics and a hint beyond it - how can a light Higgs boson possibly survive huge, destabilizing quantum effects without new, undiscovered physics? Furthermore, dark matter is known to exist from astronomical observations; however, the particle properties of dark matter remain shrouded in mystery. The combined activities of the Cornell University group address such basic questions puzzling science - the origin of mass and the particle nature of dark matter - and have the potential for surprising discoveries that may change the way we understand our physical world. 

This award will provide support Cornell's work on the CMS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, a particle physics laboratory in Geneva, Switzerland. During the three-year timeframe of this award, CMS will complete instrumentation upgrades and resume data taking.  Additionally during this period, the R&D phase for the advance upgrades of CMS for high luminosity HL-LHC operation will be completed, and major construction of new detector subsystems will be initiated.  The Cornell group serves as a project leader of the broader HL-LHC effort of the US groups on CMS, and has its own specific interests, including in the upgrade of the forward pixel tracking detector and track-triggering for the experiment.  

Among the notable broader impacts activities of the Cornell group, many include significant outreach to students and the public in the upstate New York region through Xraise, the outreach office of the Cornell  Laboratory for Accelerator-based Sciences and Education.  Xraise has developed a significant number of teaching units and science kits for a "Lending Library" that can be taken to schools or used in after-school programs to bring exciting hands-on activities to hundreds of local children.  The requests for teacher training in support of such activities have far outnumbered the availability of training opportunities.   To increase the reach of this valuable program, the Cornell group will produce videos to further expand upon the materials that are available to support the Lending Library.  This work and content development will be done in close coordination with the Xraise professional staff, to identify topic, length and target audience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported a team of particle physicists at Cornell University to study the properties of the smallest known particles and their interactions at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN). The team consists of five faculty members, four post-docs and a number of graduate students.
Our goal is to explore proton-proton collisions at the highest energy ever created in a laboratory. We participate in the Compact Muon Solenoid experiment, an international collaboration. Our work consists of analyzing collision data to study the properties of the known particles and to look for unexplained new phenomena. The main known particle under study is the Higgs Boson, which was discovered by CMS and a competing experiment (ATLAS) ten years ago. The study of its properties are crucial to test the validity of the standard model (SM) of particle physics. We continue to test the SM with our studies of the Higgs. For new phenomena, we search for new phenomena such as supersymmetry, dark matter, or exotic vector bosons.
Another major effort of our group is to prepare for the High-Luminosity upgrade of the LHC (HL-LHC). This upgrade will allow the CMS experiment to collect a data set ten times larger than before, which will allow us to increase our sensitivity to new phenomena by leaps and bounds. Our team is heavily engaged in the development and construction of the CMS upgrade, with leading roles in the development of the forward pixel detector and the inclusion of the tracking detector in the hardware trigger. This work is also supported by the National Science Foundation via the MREFC program. Cornell is the lead institution for this program, with Prof. Ryd as the PI.
During the grant period, we have trained many graduate students, including five who have gained their Ph.D.'s. These students have either moved on to industry (defense, financial, and high-tech) or gone on to post-docs in particle physics.  We have also trained many undergraduate students in our laboratory. Training a workforce is important to our faculty and working with students and post-docs is among the most rewarding parts of our jobs.  Our work is disseminated to the public in form of publications (many, including six linked specially to this grant), presentations at conferences, and public talks.
